awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Testing the contributions of selection, gene-flow, and recombination to reinforcement
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the generation of biodiversity involves figuring out how and why speciation occurs. Speciation involves the buildup of barriers to reproduction between diverging species. This buildup can result from the interplay of evolutionary forces such as natural selection and gene flow. This research investigates these evolutionary forces in a group of three native Texas Phlox wildflowers. Focusing on these three species, the research will determine how and why reproductive isolation evolves. Across Texas, these species of wildflowers can be found growing together in populations and hybridizing. This research involves a detailed investigation of what drives the evolution of traits to decrease hybridization between one pair of species and prevents the evolution of these traits in another pair. This research combines ecological studies with genetic and genomic studies. By doing so, it will test long standing hypotheses about how and why species form. This project integrates undergraduate students in a course-based research experience. This experience will allow students to study speciation hands-on and learn about the scientific method. By working with the local natural history museum, this project will engage K-12 grade students and teachers in plant evolution-based activities.

This project investigates how selection, gene flow, and recombination contribute to the evolution of reproductive isolation between co-occurring species. Phlox drummondii co-occurs with two closely related Phlox species but has evolved increased reproductive isolation with only one of these two species. To determine why reproductive isolation evolves with one species and not the other this project will measure the cost of hybridization. Further, the research will measure the strength of existing barriers to reproduction and the amount and direction of gene flow between species. This project integrates field-based studies of pollinator attraction with greenhouse studies of controlled matings and hybrid success. In addition, it will include detailed genomic studies to investigate the genetic architecture of reproductive isolation and gene flow between species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant investigates the fundamental evolutionary forces of selection, gene flow, and recombination to understand the process of species formation. Specifically, our work aims to determine how and why lineages diverge, barriers to reproduction evolve, and speciation occurs. Thus far this work has resulted in 9 peer-reviewed publications (with at least two more in preparation to be submitted) and 10 conference presentations in the form of talks or posters.

The focal system of our work is a small clade of three Phlox wildflower species that grow in overlapping ranges in Texas, USA. These species show strong but variable barriers to reproduction that include divergence in ecological habitat, pollinator behavioral isolation due to floral trait divergence, and strong hybrid sterility. Our work characterized the genetic architecture of the traits involved in these barriers, the role of selection in spreading these barriers, and the impact of these barriers on gene flow between species. Although most of our research centered around the Texas Phlox system, we also investigated these patterns in the broader diversity of the Phlox genus and across angiosperms.

A major goal of our work was to characterize patterns of pre-zygotic reproductive isolation in our system to broadly understand the role of pollinator behavior, pollen-pistil interactions, and ecological niche divergence in speciation. We advance this field with three publications exploring the role of pollinator behavior in controlling gene flow, phenology, and patterns of hybridization in plants. Within the Phlox system we also perform detailed field experiments to characterize the pollination biology of the system. We further our understanding of pollen-pistil interactions and their role in speciation in two publications that investigate mechanical barriers to reproduction between species through mechanisms of autonomous selfing and divergence in style length. Finally, we perform extensive experiments in natural field settings and in the greenhouse to explore role of selection in driving patterns of divergence across species. One of these projects has been published and another is about to be submitted. These projects demonstrate the multidimensionality of natural selection that shapes patterns of adaptation between and within species.

A second major goal of our work was to characterize patterns of post-zygotic reproductive isolation in our system. We discovered strong hybrid sterility in both pollen and ovules suggesting extensive genetic incompatibilities. In some cases, the strength of the sterility was highly dependent on the direction of the cross and thus indicates interactions between nuclear genes and genes on the mitochondrial or chloroplast genomes. We are currently using genetic mapping to locate the genomic loci causing these incompatibilities and will be preparing our work for publication soon.

A third major goal of our research was to quantify patterns of divergence and gene flow across Phlox. We have generated a revised phylogeny for this group with genome sequence data and tested long-standing hypotheses about the formation of hybrid species and patterns of gene flow across the genus. Across two publications we demonstrate that, although hybridization was common throughout the clade and did contribute to generating diversity, the patterns of phenotypic variation supporting wide-spread hybridization are not always supported by genetic data.

The final major accomplishment of this work was designing and implementing a new undergraduate-research experience course for freshman students. This course allowed hands-on experiences for students in designing experiments, collecting scientific data, analyzing and interpreting the data, and presenting their findings. Through structured feedback and evaluation, we could demonstrate that this hands-on course improved students’ comfort in the lab, and desire to pursue a scientific career.

The broader impacts of this project have included public education activities, training of scientists, and generating publicly available educational science material about plant speciation. This grant has supported the research, training, and professional development of four postdoctoral researchers, two graduate students, three post-baccalaureate research technicians, and three independent undergraduate researchers as well as the education and inspiration of undergraduate students in the associated research course.  The people supported by this award distributed the science through publications and the broader importance of science by engagement with the public. Specifically, we have worked with the Arnold Arboretum Young Scientist program that brings kids into nature to teach them about plants, and participated in teacher training and professional development programs for Boston-area science teachers. Our work has engaged more broadly with the public through our scientists starting the very popular Let’s Botanize plant science outreach channel on TikTok and Instagram, teaching an outreach class on plant-pollinator interactions and floral diversity for the Arnold Arboretum YouTube Channel, and producing an educational video with “Science in Real Life” about plant speciation.
